0.text: G'day viewers my name's Graeme Stevenson and like to

4.text: invite yo to come on a journey of creativity and learning and adventure through the series

8.text: Colour In Your Life. There's an artist in every family throughout the world.

12.text: Lots of times there's an artist deep down inside all of us as well.

16.text: So grab your kids, your brothers, your sisters, your aunties,

20.text: uncles, and mums and dads and come and see how some of the best artists

24.text: in Australia do what they do.

64.text: and welcome back to Colour In Your Life. Well we're down in Victoria, at a beautiful town called

68.text: Healesville, and I'm with a very talented lady, Lynette Orzlowski.

72.text: (Lynette) Thanks Graeme. (Graeme) How are you Darling? (Lynette)  Good. How are you?  (Graeme) Great to be here. Now Lynette is

76.text: an award winning, multi award winning artist, she's won over one hundred awards

80.text: which is amazing, and also a multi disciplined artist as

84.text: well. Lynette is disciplined with pastels, with oils

88.text: with acrylics. And today - which is really cool because we haven't had this on before

92.text: she's also an airbrush artist, and she's going to take us through a bunch of things with airbrush

96.text: today which is fascinating. And when you see the quality of her work you'll perfectly

100.text: understand what I'm talking about. I mean she uses a number of different ideas to put

104.text: into her work. Loves animals and you've really been working on horses

108.text: for a long time. So tell me how the airbrushing and the horses actually came about? How does that fit together

112.text: for you? (Lynette) Well I've been airbrushing for about sixteen, seventeen years

116.text: now. (Graeme) Okay. (Lynette) And the horses were something that I had in

120.text: my younger life. I use to ride horses, use to

124.text: have horses, and now it's sort of transferred into my daughter riding

128.text: horses  - and she Events. So I get to go out there with camera and

132.text: take a lot of shots. And literally the airbrush is a tool that I've

136.text: used for quiet a few years, and now I'm just putting it into practice on

140.text: the canvas. (Graeme) That's fantastic. And obviously there's a lot of studs

144.text: in the area. (Lynette) There are, yeah there are. They're all

148.text: diversified as well so you know, you've got racehorses, you've got Friesian's,

152.text: you've got Quarter Horses, you've got Thoroughbreds, you've got pony

156.text: clubbers all that sort of stuff, so lots of different horses. (Graeme) The difference with the airbrush

160.text: is you can get a lot done but still, as easy as

164.text: it looks, there's a lot that's involved in actually building it. And it's layers

168.text: of airbrushing that you ave to build up, (Lynette) Yeah, absolutely. (Graeme) a little similar to normal painting

172.text: but the fact is it's pretty well dry as soon as it hits the canvas isn't it?(Lynette) Yep, that's right.

176.text: (Graeme) Yeah, so alright we're going to go through this, this is really interesting stuff. I mean I used to

180.text: do this as a young man myself and I find it quite fascinating but come on the journey.

184.text: We are going to do some backgrounds initially which is similar to this one here.

188.text: (Lynette) Yep. (Graeme) And then Lynette is actually going to start to work on this particular piece right here as well, and it's

192.text: going to be fantastic so come along for the ride.

204.text: Lynette, now you've got the blank canvas up there. Now one thing you did say to me just

208.text: before we started was you use the best canvas. (Lynette) Yes I do. (Graeme) And what is

212.text: that? (Lynette) It is from Art Spectrum, and it is the

216.text: Claessens Belgian linen stretched canvas. (Graeme) You can't get any better can you? (Lynette) It's beautiful.

220.text: (Graeme) It's fantastic stuff so what you're going to do is, using the Golden acrylics

224.text: (Lynette) Yes. (Graeme) and you're going to do - I don't know how you do what you're doing of course, but

228.text: you're going to do that effect, the background effect for us. (Lynette) Yep, absolutely, so (Graeme) How do we start?

232.text: (Lynette) what I do with my paintings is, I have a like a real

236.text: wash effect. So this one I'm doing a little bit different to what

240.text: I'm going to demonstrate later, but this is the same sort of style so it

244.text: sort of going to be a bit old worldly sort of,

248.text: sort of have a little bit of stencilling in it and stuff like that, so we'll go through that. (Graeme) Excellent.

252.text: (Lynette) So I'm just going to start with some Raw Umber, from Golden. Now there is a medium that you

256.text: can put into it, and I do use a liquid glazing medium,

260.text: but only a little bit cause it doesn't really need it actually.

264.text: (Graeme) I love the fact that your table is your palette. (Lynette) Yes.

268.text: (Graeme) It's great. (Lynette) Oh look, I've had palettes before that have just been a board.

272.text: With acrylic, because of the way they dry you can't just scrape them off. (Graeme) Yep.

276.text: (Lynette) So just using a little bit of water, (Graeme) Yep. (Lynette) now I did have the

280.text: background painted, but I needed that dry so I can show you what I do in the

284.text: second layer. (Graeme) Okay. Was it gesso you painted the background with? (Lynette) No, no, it's actually

288.text: Golden Raw Umber with Titanium White. (Graeme) Okay. (Lynette) So

292.text: it's the same sort of tonal that I've got

296.text: the Raw Umber (Graeme) Yep. (Lynette) but just really lightened off. These Belgian linens are

300.text: actually primed in acrylic. You can get them in oil as well, if you want to do oils,

304.text: (Graeme)  Yep. (Lynette) but this is acrylic primed. (Graeme) Yes if you're

308.text: going to do great work you may as well have the best. (Lynette) Yeah, exactly.

312.text: (Graeme) You've very much involved in the arts in the area. I mean to

316.text: the extent that some of the memberships that you actually have are with:

320.text: Illustrators Australia, the Wildlife Artist Society of Australasia, the Australia

324.text: Gild of Realist Artist, Illustrators Australia, the Yarra Rangers Photographic

328.text: Society, Institute of Equine Art Association.

332.text: Do you find that being a member of all those institutes

336.text: helps you with your connections? (Lynette) It does, absolutely and I really, really

340.text: enjoy when I actually get time to go to the meetings

344.text: and you know, join their exhibitions and stuff like that. I

348.text: do find with a busy life of painting and everything like that, it's very hard to get around

352.text: around to them all. But yeah, I enjoy

356.text: being with them all. They give you a little bit of information all the time

360.text: so it's great. (Graeme) So this is a really loose

364.text: mixture that you've got here. It's mostly water and then just sort of

368.text: obviously got a big brush there as well - letting, letting the paint sort of

372.text: do its own thing. (Lynette) Yeah, sometimes it needs extra layers, extra

376.text: colours, there could be drying time in between, until you get

380.text: the desired effect. (Graeme) Yep, so you've got a spray bottle there. (Lynette) I have a

384.text: spray bottle just with water. (Graeme) Yep. (Lynette) I can actually use a spray

388.text: bottle with metho in it if I wanted to, to breakup that paint. (Graeme) Aha.

392.text: (Lynette) It doesn't damage the paint it just separates it from the canvas. (Graeme) Yep. (Lynette) So

396.text: this one I want it to be a little bit more Baroque style, sort of old world

400.text: sort of something you would see on an old building. (Graeme) Yep, and that's just

404.text: Golden acrylic white. (Lynette) Golden Acrylic Titanium White.

408.text: (Graeme) Okay. (Lynette) Absolutely, so I'm not actually watering this one down as much, so I'm getting

412.text: a little bit more of a stronger effect. But then if I don't like it, then I can

416.text: come back over with my squirt bottle and water it up again. (Graeme) Okay.

420.text: (Lynette) So I'm just going to squirt a bit more water just to make it run, just to break it up a little

424.text: bit more. So that's it, (Graeme) A great looking background. (Lynette) we need to let that dry.

444.text: (Lynette) Once I've done the background and I've marked out my image, I

448.text: then block in with white. So I'm just using the Golden High Flow

456.text: for you know, pen and ink, airbrush, anything like that so it's nice and thin.

460.text: So yeah, I use a mixture of that

464.text: which I'm going to strain. (Graeme) And that's actually a strainer.

468.text: (Lynette) That's actually a automotive stainer yeah, so it's a real fine

472.text: strainer. So any impurities or any

476.text: you know, extra sort of you know, lumps of pigment

480.text: that are in the paint will actually be strainer out. The reason why

484.text: I do this is cause the airbrush that I'm using which is a HPC

488.text: Iwata airbrush. That's a point three eight needle. I don't change needles

492.text: I use the same needle so I need it to be

496.text: actually quite fine to go through. (Graeme) And what are you putting in there now? (Lynette) Okay, so what

500.text: I'm adding is a little bit of airbrush Transparent Extender. (Graeme) Yeah. (Lynette) I just

504.text: find that it happens with the flow, (Graeme) Okay. (Lynette) cause what happens is

508.text: acrylics have a tendency to tip dry, and I just find with

512.text: that little bit of airbrush Extender it's not going to tip dry as much. (Graeme) Okay.

516.text: And you sort of get beading at the end of that little needle. (Lynette) More than beading it's actually just dry

520.text: paint. (Graeme) Okay (Lynette) Yeah, so I'm going to start.

524.text: So just working off my reference here. (Graeme) Do you normally wear a mask at all?

528.text: (Lynette) With automative - absolutely, (Graeme) Yep. (Lynette) and I normally do

532.text: in the studio but because we're filming it would look really silly me to talk

536.text: to you with a mask on. So as you can see I can come in and do some

540.text: really nice sharp lines, and then the rest of it I can sort of just

544.text: bring the airbrush back off the canvas and I just

548.text: hazes in. (Graeme) The viewers mightn't understand that the reason you

552.text: keep spraying it on your hand is to check for moisture. (Lynette) It's not just that

556.text: Graeme, it is  (Graeme) Yeah. (Lynette) and with moisture it will actually effect

560.text: your painting and you won't be able to paint, (Graeme) Yeah. (Lynette) cause it will spirt out water

564.text: onto your painting, especially using acrylics and water based

568.text: it doesn't work.  But no, it's actually to

572.text: clean the tip, because what happens is when you shut down

576.text: your airbrush a little bit of paint sits on your needle, and a lot

580.text: lot of people that have started airbrushing will find when they start their airbrush up on their

584.text: page, they'll get splats of paint (Graeme) Okay. (Lynette) and at least this

588.text: eliminates it. So what I'm doing is I'm cleaning that needle first, making

592.text: sure there's no paint and it's ready to go. (Graeme) And you can see the effects

596.text: that you can get, and it's pretty well drying as soon as it hits the

600.text: canvas. (Lynette) Yeah, there's a little bit that you can rub

604.text: off, but because yeah, it's been blown by the air

784.text: coloring in like a coloring book - in a way. (Graeme) Oh and the other

936.text: to bring in some detail of the eye as well, and you get these beautiful

948.text: (Lynette) It is, and you know when it comes to real sharp detail

952.text: (Graeme) Yep. (Lynette) you've got to be really precise (Graeme) Yep. (Lynette) and it's just

960.text: here is I'm just going over my darks again, just reinforcing

964.text: that color. (Graeme) Aha. You just get to the stage were you're refining, refining,

972.text: on this one I can't see a lot of his veins - I've got a few in

980.text: painting as well. (Graeme) So you say airbrush is your favourite

984.text: medium? (Lynette) Yeah, it is actually. I really,

988.text: really enjoy the fact that you can get this

1000.text: what it is to do with airbrush (Graeme) Oh god yeah. (Lynette) and I just find that yeah, the

1004.text: technique that is used to get these, these finished pieces

1008.text: I really enjoy. (Graeme) Yeah, if you were painting that

1012.text: with oils or acrylics you'd wouldn't

1016.text: be anywhere near you are now. (Lynette) Oh no, (Graeme) Yeah. (Lynette) no. So just coming in

1020.text: with a little bit more detail here. Now I've really colored up the

1024.text: where the pupils going to go, so just need to dry

1028.text: that off so I'm just blowing cold air onto it, or the compressed air.

1032.text: So I've just picked up the white airbrush, not to say that it is a

1036.text: white airbrush: it's silver. But I've actually picked up my second airbrush that I had

1040.text: the white in previously, and I'm just going to start on the muzzle. (Graeme) There's a lot

1044.text: of artists do use stencils but you're that proficient at doing this

1048.text: that you do it mostly freehand which is, it's not - it

1052.text: looks easy, but it's really not easy to do. (Lynette) No, you're right.

1056.text: It's a lot of practice. So I'm over highlighting, just

1060.text: so I can get that white back in, and then obviously we'll knock that back with

1064.text: another set of colors. (Graeme) I was going to say with your

1068.text: commissioned pieces you go right out; I mean you prefer to take your own photos.

1088.text: and I get to see their personality, their

1092.text: traits, what best light suits them as well. So yeah, I

1108.text: beautiful daughter, the darlingist person in your life. (Lynette) Yeah, she's beautiful.

1116.text: with horses a great deal; you understand them. (Lynette) Well she does not only dressage but she

1120.text: does all three disciplines: dressage, showjumping and the cross

1124.text: country. So she does a lot of horse trails and eventing, so I'm out there in the field

1128.text: and them come back into the studio and start painting them as references.

1132.text: (Graeme) Okay, well I can see there you've just picked up a palette and a

1136.text: brush. You're just getting those super fine lines and then highlighting everything

1140.text: with the brush. Now in saying that as well, a lot of the work that you do, you do

1144.text: pastel, and you do oils, and you do acrylics. You do combine

1148.text: your airbrushing with your painting style as well. (Lynette) Yeah, in some of the

1152.text: pieces I actually do; I'm just not solely an airbrush artist

1156.text: even though I do use the tool a lot. With my commissions they're not soley based on

1160.text: the airbrush, I do actually do pastels, watercolors, acrylics.

1164.text: Even though I do really enjoy the airbrush and I love painting with

1168.text: it - depends on the subject - I don't have to use it all the time. So at the moment

1172.text: with this I'm actually using the High Flow,

1176.text: using the brush with the High Flow paint. I just find

1180.text: that it's already pre-thinned. You don't have to, have to worry about

1184.text: watering it down or using a medium or anything like that. I do have

1188.text: the Heavy Body Titanium there if I do need to use it or want it a little bit thicker.

1192.text: But I'm just finding that with this fine Rigger brush it's

1196.text: just working perfectly with it. So basically what I'm doing is I've got that

1200.text: out of focus airbrushing on the mane, and then what I'm doing

1204.text: is I'm bringing that depth of field so with the detail. Which

1208.text: with everything with these pieces, it's all getting in your layers

1212.text: with your highlights, and then knocking it back down with your dark tones. Okay, now

1216.text: that I've actually done the brushwork that I'm happy with, I'm just

1220.text: going to come in with my white airbrush and just finish

1224.text: off a little bit more highlighting. So now I'm just doing short strokes,

1228.text: just to create the direction of the hairs going. These are

1232.text: really, really short dagger strokes we call them, in the airbrush world.
